questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of difficulty swallowing, a foreign body sensation at the back of his throat, and trouble breathing at night. He has just recovered from an upper respiratory tract infection that began 5 days ago. On questioning, he reports that he has had similar symptoms in the past each time he has had an upper respiratory tract infection. Physical examination shows a 3 x 2-cm, nontender, rubbery midline mass at the base of the tongue. His skin is dry and cool. An image of his technetium-99m pertechnetate scan is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patientâ€™s condition?

choices.text: Ductal obstruction of the sublingual salivary glands
Chronic infection of the palatine and lingual tonsils
Arrested endodermal migration from pharyngeal floor
Persistent epithelial tract between the foramen cecum and thyroid isthmus
Failure of obliteration of the second branchial cleft

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ductal obstruction of the sublingual salivary glands would cause backup of secretions, resulting in a mucocele on the floor of the mouth (i.e., a ranula). While this could theoretically cause this patient's dysphagia and dyspnea, it would not explain his abnormal technetium-99m scan.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic tonsillitis of the palatine and lingual tonsils would cause adenotonsillar hypertrophy. This could be exacerbated by URIs and cause dysphagia and dyspnea, all of which would apply to this patient. However, adenotonsillar hypertrophy does not explain the mass at the base of the tongue or the abnormal uptake on this patient's technetium-99m scan.

C) CORRECT:

Arrested endodermal migration of the thyroid gland from the pharyngeal floor describes the process by which a thyroglossal duct cyst or ectopic thyroid can arise. This patient's technetium-99m scan shows thyroid tissue within the tongue, the most common location of ectopic thyroid tissue. As in this case, enlargement of ectopic thyroid is common with URIs due to the thyroid's lymphoid tissue and can cause dysphagia and dyspnea. Surgical removal of a lingual thyroid may result in hypothyroidism if there is no other site of thyroid tissue. Some patients with thyroid ectopia develop symptoms of hypothyroidism, which could explain this patient's dry and cool skin.

D) INCORRECT:

A persistent epithelial tract between the foramen cecum (tongue) and thyroid isthmus describes the thyroglossal duct. A thyroglossal duct cyst can arise anywhere along this tract and may become enlarged or inflamed after a URI, like with this patient. However, inflammation would be expected at the anterior neck (i.e., midline mass), rather than the tongue. Furthermore, a technetium-99m scan in a patient with a thyroglossal duct cyst would show uptake at the normally positioned thyroid gland, which is not the case here.

E) INCORRECT:

Failure of obliteration of the second branchial cleft describes the cause of a branchial cleft cyst. While branchial cleft cysts can result in neck masses, which this patient has, they are usually located laterally and inferior to the pharynx, and also do not typically enlarge following URIs. Furthermore, a branchial cleft cyst does not contain thyroid tissue or explain this patient's abnormal technetium-99m scan.
questions.hint: The technetium-99m thyroid scan shows radioisotope uptake at the base of the tongue and the hyoid region, but no uptake in the normal location of the thyroid on the anterior neck, findings which suggest an ectopic thyroid gland.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a neck mass and hoarseness. He has no history of major medical illness. Physical examination shows a 2.5-cm fixed, irregular thyroid nodule. His serum calcitonin concentration is elevated. The nodule is most likely composed of cells that are embryologically derived from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The paired inferior parathyroid glands are derived from the third branchial pouch. The parathyroids produce PTH, which is elevated in primary hyperparathyroidism. Elevated PTH levels cause hypercalcemia, which results in a compensatory increase in serum calcitonin. However, primary hyperparathyroidism most commonly occurs due to a parathyroid adenoma, which is rarely palpable and would not manifest with hoarseness or a fixed mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Derivatives of the fourth branchial arch include the cartilage of the larynx, several muscles of the larynx and pharynx, and the superior laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve. None of these structures secrete or influence the secretion of calcitonin, which is elevated in this case.

C) CORRECT:

The two lateral thyroid anlagen differentiate from ultimobranchial bodies, the most caudal, or ultimate, structures derived from the fourth branchial pouch. The lateral anlagen then fuse with the median thyroid anlage to form the thyroid gland. The parafollicular C cells are thought to be derived from the endoderm of the lateral thyroid anlage and secrete calcitonin. Medullary thyroid cancer arises from these cells and can manifest as a firm, painless thyroid nodule, as well as hoarseness and elevated serum calcitonin levels, which are all seen in this case. The findings of recent experimental studies argue strongly against the previous hypothesis that parafollicular C cells are derived from the neural crest.

The endodermal cells of the median thyroid anlage differentiate into thyroid follicular cells.

D) INCORRECT:

The surface ectoderm gives rise to the epidermis, hair, nails, inner ear, external ear, enamel of teeth, lens of the eyes, anterior pituitary, parotid gland, and the anal canal (below the pectinate line). Although a tumor of the epidermis could manifest as a neck mass, it would not be expected to cause elevated serum calcitonin.

E) INCORRECT:

The cells of the second branchial pouch differentiate into the epithelial tissue lining the tonsils. Since the deep cervical lymph nodes receive lymphatic drainage from the tonsils, tonsillitis or lymphoma in the area could manifest as cervical lymphadenopathy. However, an alteration in serum calcitonin levels would not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's hoarseness and fixed, irregular thyroid nodule should raise concern for invasive thyroid cancer. His elevated calcitonin suggests medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, a tumor derived from parafollicular C cells.

questions.text: An investigator is studying a drug that acts on the thyroid hormone pathway. Levels of serum free T3 and T4 in healthy participants are measured before and after administration of the drug. After administration, there is a decrease in the average serum free T3 level, while the average serum free T4 level is increased compared to initial serum studies. Inhibition of which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thyroid follicular proteases release T3 and T4 from thyroglobulin so that they can enter peripheral circulation and reach peripheral tissues. Inhibition would decrease the average serum levels of both T3 and T4.
Image Description:

Thyroglobulin (TG) is produced in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of the follicular cells. In the Golgi apparatus, TG is packed in vesicles and released into the colloid via exocytosis.

Iodide (I-) is taken up in the follicular cells via the basolateral Na+/I- symporter, which is driven by Na+/K+-ATPase. Iodine diffuses to the apex of the cell and is transported into the colloid via the Pendrin transporter.

The enzyme thyroid peroxidase (TPO) catalyzes the biosynthesis of the thyroid hormones T3 and T4 and their precursors monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT), which are all attached to the TG molecule stored in the colloid.

For the release of thyroid hormones, TG is taken up by the follicular cells via endocytosis. Following fusion with a lysosome, proteolytic enzymes cleave TG to release T3, T4, DIT, and MIT. T3 and T4 are released into the blood (via the MCT8 transporter). Deiodinase removes the iodine from the MIT and DIT; iodine is then re-added to the intracellular I- pool.

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) from the pituitary gland stimulates the basolateral uptake of iodine, as well as the biosynthesis and release of thyroid hormones.

B) INCORRECT:

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is synthesized in the anterior pituitary gland and stimulates the release of T3 and T4 from the thyroid gland. An inhibition of TSH (e.g., due to somatostatin) would decrease the average serum levels of both T3 and T4.
Image Description:

Thyroglobulin (TG) is produced in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of the follicular cells. In the Golgi apparatus, TG is packed in vesicles and released into the colloid via exocytosis.

Iodide (I-) is taken up in the follicular cells via the basolateral Na+/I- symporter, which is driven by Na+/K+-ATPase. Iodine diffuses to the apex of the cell and is transported into the colloid via the Pendrin transporter.

The enzyme thyroid peroxidase (TPO) catalyzes the biosynthesis of the thyroid hormones T3 and T4 and their precursors monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT), which are all attached to the TG molecule stored in the colloid.

For the release of thyroid hormones, TG is taken up by the follicular cells via endocytosis. Following fusion with a lysosome, proteolytic enzymes cleave TG to release T3, T4, DIT, and MIT. T3 and T4 are released into the blood (via the MCT8 transporter). Deiodinase removes the iodine from the MIT and DIT; iodine is then re-added to the intracellular I- pool.

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) from the pituitary gland stimulates the basolateral uptake of iodine, as well as the biosynthesis and release of thyroid hormones.

C) INCORRECT:

By catalyzing the deiodination of monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT), iodotyrosine deiodinase is responsible for recycling free MIT and DIT and returning to T3 and T4 synthesis. Inhibiting iodotyrosine deiodinase would decrease the iodide available for thyroid hormone synthesis and therefore eventually decrease serum levels of both T3 and T4.
Image Description:

Thyroglobulin (TG) is produced in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of the follicular cells. In the Golgi apparatus, TG is packed in vesicles and released into the colloid via exocytosis.

Iodide (I-) is taken up in the follicular cells via the basolateral Na+/I- symporter, which is driven by Na+/K+-ATPase. Iodine diffuses to the apex of the cell and is transported into the colloid via the Pendrin transporter.

The enzyme thyroid peroxidase (TPO) catalyzes the biosynthesis of the thyroid hormones T3 and T4 and their precursors monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT), which are all attached to the TG molecule stored in the colloid.

For the release of thyroid hormones, TG is taken up by the follicular cells via endocytosis. Following fusion with a lysosome, proteolytic enzymes cleave TG to release T3, T4, DIT, and MIT. T3 and T4 are released into the blood (via the MCT8 transporter). Deiodinase removes the iodine from the MIT and DIT; iodine is then re-added to the intracellular I- pool.

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) from the pituitary gland stimulates the basolateral uptake of iodine, as well as the biosynthesis and release of thyroid hormones.

D) INCORRECT:

Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) catalyzes the oxidation of iodide and the coupling of monoiodotyrosine (MIT) to diiodotyrosine (DIT), important precursors in the biosynthesis of T3 and T4. Inhibition of thyroid peroxidase (e.g., due to PTU, methimazole) would decrease the serum levels of both T3 and T4.
Image Description:

Thyroglobulin (TG) is produced in the rough endoplasmic reticulum of the follicular cells. In the Golgi apparatus, TG is packed in vesicles and released into the colloid via exocytosis.

Iodide (I-) is taken up in the follicular cells via the basolateral Na+/I- symporter, which is driven by Na+/K+-ATPase. Iodine diffuses to the apex of the cell and is transported into the colloid via the Pendrin transporter.

The enzyme thyroid peroxidase (TPO) catalyzes the biosynthesis of the thyroid hormones T3 and T4 and their precursors monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT), which are all attached to the TG molecule stored in the colloid.

For the release of thyroid hormones, TG is taken up by the follicular cells via endocytosis. Following fusion with a lysosome, proteolytic enzymes cleave TG to release T3, T4, DIT, and MIT. T3 and T4 are released into the blood (via the MCT8 transporter). Deiodinase removes the iodine from the MIT and DIT; iodine is then re-added to the intracellular I- pool.

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) from the pituitary gland stimulates the basolateral uptake of iodine, as well as the biosynthesis and release of thyroid hormones.

E) CORRECT:

Peripheral 5'-deiodinase converts the less potent T4 into the biologically active T3 (which binds nuclear receptors with significantly higher affinity than T4). Inhibition of 5'-deiodinase results in an increase in the average serum T4 level and a decrease in the average serum T3 level. Drugs that inhibit 5'-deiodinase, such as propylthiouracil, are used in patients with hyperthyroidism. PTU also inhibits thyroid peroxidase.
Image Description:

Left side: effect of drugs on the thyroid gland.
- Thionamides inhibit thyroid peroxidase (TPO), which blocks thyroid hormone synthesis.
- Lithium inhibits the release of thyroid hormones and may be used off-label in a thyroid storm.
- Perchlorate inhibits the sodium-iodine cotransporter in the membrane, which blocks iodide uptake in the thyroid gland.

Right side: drug effects in the periphery. A number of drugs inhibit the enzyme deiodinase, which blocks the peripheral conversion of T4 to the active form T3.
questions.hint: This is the mechanism of action of propylthiouracil (PTU).

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks gestation comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit. Today, she feels well. She has no history of serious illness. Her pulse is 75/min and blood pressure is 110/74 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a pregnancy consistent in size with a 10-week gestation. Serum studies in this patient are most likely to show which of the following sets of laboratory values?



Thyroid-binding globulin
Free Triiodothyronine (T3)
Free Thyroxine (T4)
Total T3+T4



A
â†‘
normal
normal
â†‘


B
â†“
normal
normal
â†“


C
Normal
normal
normal
normal


D
Normal
â†‘
â†‘
â†‘


E
â†“
â†“
normal
â†“
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The hyperestrogenic state during pregnancy stimulates the synthesis of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG) by the liver and increases the glycosylation of TBG. This process slows the clearance of TBG, increasing its serum level. As more free T3 and T4bind to TBG, the level of free thyroid hormones decreases. Consequently, the pituitary gland secretes more TSH, resulting in increased synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones. This achieves a new equilibrium in which the total T3 and T4 levels (i.e., bound and unbound T3 and T4) are increased, while the free T3 and T4 levels are normal.

These changes also occur in women taking oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy, and in patients with estrogen-producing tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

This set of thyroid function test is typically seen in conditions that cause thyroid-binding globulin deficiency (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, cirrhosis), which leads to a higher level of free T3 and T4. Consequently, TSH secretion is suppressed, and the new equilibrium shows decreased total T3 and T4 levels with normal free T3 and T4 levels.

C) INCORRECT:

This set of thyroid function test is typically seen in a healthy nonpregnant person. However, the hyperestrogenic state in pregnancy results in physiological changes that would alter this patient's thyroid function test.

D) INCORRECT:

A thyroid function test that shows an increase in the free and total T3 and T4 levels is typically seen in hyperthyroidism. Although hCG, which increases significantly during pregnancy, has a thyrotropic activity, this patient is clinically euthyroid (i.e., normal heart rate and blood pressure and no symptoms of hyperthyroidism).

E) INCORRECT:

A normal free T4 level in the setting of decreased thyroid-binding globulin, free T3, and total T3 and T4 levels can be seen in sick euthyroid syndrome. Sick euthyroid syndrome is seen in severely ill patients and is therefore unlikely in this healthy pregnant patient.
questions.hint: The patient is clinically euthyroid despite her hyperestrogenic state, which causes alterations in the metabolism of certain types of proteins.
